awd_titl_txt: NSF/FDA SIR: Robust, Reliable, and Trustworthy Regulatory Science Tool for Stroke Recovery Assessment using Hybrid Brain-Muscle Functional Coupling Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Stroke is the leading cause of age-related motor disabilities and is becoming more prevalent in younger populations. The development of post-stroke motor rehabilitation technologies is at an all-time high. Many of these technologies claim to accelerate recovery. However, subjective and coarse evaluation of motor capacities have generated inconsistent recommendations regarding rehabilitation devices. There is a need for the development of a robust, reliable, and accessible biomarker for post-stroke recovery. Such a biomarker could be used as a regulatory science tool (RST) that improves the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) review process for rehabilitation device applications. This proposal focuses on the design and validation of a robust and high-fidelity marker of recovery, considering the directional information exchange between regions of the central and peripheral nervous systems. There is currently no approved RST for assessing the efficacy of rehabilitative devices for post-stroke motor recovery. This research is a collaboration between New York University and the FDA, and represents a unique joint effort from the clinical, engineering, and regulatory sectors. The project will include seminars and undergraduate research to promote STEM education with a focus on engaging students from underrepresented groups.

The central goal of this project is to implement a noninvasive biomarker that demystifies the directional (afferent and efferent), nonlinear, and complex patterns of neural communication, realizing a “neurophysiological magnifier” that objectively quantifies degradation in the interaction between anatomy, activation, and pathway in post-stroke patients. The project will analyze the reliability and efficacy of the proposed biomarker based on data acquired from recovering stroke patients with the goal of developing the first-ever stroke-focused rehabilitation RST. For this, the project (1) proposes a mechanistic view of the modulations of afferent and efferent neural pathways in correlation with motor performance and mobility, (2) quantifies the cortical sources involved in sensorimotor processing after stroke and their connectivity to the motor units in muscles, (3) establishes corticomuscular biomarkers that predict motor performance and mobility for stroke patients, and (4)  performs inter-and intra-subject reliability analyses in addition to validation analyses using independent datasets. This project will also promote FDA regulatory science on next-generation brain-machine interfaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview: This research aimed to create a reliable and objective method to measure motor disability and recovery in stroke survivors. Stroke is a leading cause of long-term disability, and while therapeutic advancements, such as robotic rehabilitation devices, have improved recovery options, current methods for assessing stroke recovery are often subjective. There is a pressing need for an objective tool to evaluate both disability and the effectiveness of therapeutic options. Our project sought to address this gap by developing novel biomarkers—measurable indicators in the body that reflect the underlying neural changes associated with stroke recovery.

Key Outcomes and Findings:

  • Novel Biomarkers for Post-Stroke Disability: Our team developed a new biomarker called Wide-band Neural Information Coupling (WiNiCo) to better understand how the brain and muscles communicate and coordinate after a stroke. We measured electrical activity from the brain (EEG) and muscles (EMG) of stroke patients and healthy individuals, highlighting how stroke disrupts neural communication and coordination. We introduced the Entropy of Nonlinear Corticomuscular Connectivity (EnCMC), a metric that quantifies these disruptions, serving as an indicator of motor impairment. This allows for more objective and precise evaluation of stroke recovery and disability.

  • Advancement in Neural and Muscular Connectivity Analysis: We developed new methods to study how different muscles work together after a stroke using EMG data. Our Information-Theory-Based Functional Muscle Network (InfoMuNet) detected even subtle improvements in synergistic muscle coordination, demonstrating its value as a sensitive tool for tracking recovery.

  • Technological Innovation: Our project also led to the development of a wearable sensor system that captures muscle activity through mechanomyography (MMG), overcoming the limitations of traditional methods in noisy environments. This technology enables researchers and clinicians to track muscle activity in unstructured real-world environments, allowing for more accessible rehabilitation solutions outside of research lab and clinic settings.

  • Machine Learning and Deep Learning for BioSignal Processing: We incorporated machine learning techniques to enhance the accuracy of our biomarkers. These models helped filter out noise in neural and muscular data, making our results more reliable. By analyzing patterns of muscle activity, our deep-learning models can predict movement intentions and provide insights into the quality of motion.

Broader Impacts:

  • Improving Stroke Recovery:
    By creating more accurate and objective ways to measure motor disability and recovery, the outcomes of our project can potentially help clinicians better assess the effectiveness of rehabilitation technologies. This could lead to more personalized treatment plans for stroke patients, resulting in improved outcomes and quality of life.

  • Applications Beyond Stroke:
    The biomarkers and technologies we developed have the potential to be applied to other neurological conditions that affect movement control. Additionally, the wearable sensor technology and machine learning techniques have broader applications in fields such as medical robotics, prosthetics, and human-machine interfaces, helping to create more adaptive and responsive assistive devices.

In summary, this project has made significant contributions to the scientific understanding of post-stroke movement disability. Our findings, published in high-impact journals, promote future advancements in stroke rehabilitation technologies and open new avenues for interdisciplinary research and innovation.
